Given a vehicle of size <math>S</math> and distance <math>x</math>, the [[visual angle]] is: <math>\theta=2\arctan{\left (\tfrac{S}{2x} \right)}</math>. Its [[Differentiation of trigonometric functions#Differentiating the inverse tangent function|derivative]] with respect to distance is <math>\tfrac{d\theta}{dx}=\tfrac{-4S}{S^2+4x^2}</math>. An approaching vehicle of constant [[velocity]] <math>v</math> will decrease the distance at [[Rate (mathematics)|rate]] <math>\tfrac{dx}{dt}=-v</math>. The time rate of visual expansion is obtained from the rate at which the [[subtended angle]] grows with decreased distance, multiplied by the rate at which the distance lessens with time: <math>\tfrac{d\theta}{dt}=\tfrac{\operatorname{d}\!\theta}{\operatorname{d}\!x}\cdot\tfrac{\operatorname{d}\!x}{\operatorname{d}\!t}</math>. It follows that <math>\frac{4S \cdot v}{S^2+4x^2} \gtrsim \dot{\theta_{t}}</math>. Hence, an approaching vehicle's looming motion is not perceivable until <math>x \lesssim \sqrt{\frac{S \cdot v}{\dot{\theta_{t}}}-\frac{S^2}{4}}</math>, where the {{math|{{sfrac|S<sup>2</sup>|4}}}} term is omitted with [[small-angle approximation]]. The [[units of measurement]] for size, distance, and velocity variables must be of the same system (i.e. multiply by {{math|{{sfrac|22|15}}}} to convert [[Miles per hour|MPH]] to [[Foot per second|ft/s]] or {{math|{{sfrac|5|18}}}} to convert [[Kilometres per hour|km/h]] to [[Metre per second|m/s]] or {{math|{{sfrac|π|180}}}} to convert [[Degree (angle)|deg]] to requisite [[radians|rad]]). [http://www.visualexpert.com/Resources/rearendcollision.html Read more about this topic]|group="Note"}} Vehicles that are approaching an intersection from beyond the [[Visual acuity#Subtended Angular Velocity Detection Threshold .28SAVT.29|SAVT]] limit cannot be reliably distinguished between moving or parked, though they may be traveling at such an imprudent speed as to pose an immediate hazard. In this circumstance, it is impossible for the entering driver to have fair notice that his or her contemplated conduct is forbidden by such hazard,<ref name="269 US 385">{{cite court |litigants=[[Connally v. General Construction Co.]] |vol=269 |reporter=[[United States Reports]] |opinion=385 |pinpoint=391 |court=[[Supreme Court of the United States]] |date=January 4, 1926 |url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/269/385/case.html |accessdate=February 2016 |quote=That the terms of a penal statute creating a new offense must be sufficiently explicit to inform those who are subject to it what conduct on their part will render them liable to its penalties is a well recognized requirement, consonant alike with ordinary notions of fair play and the settled rules of law, and a statute which either forbids or requires the doing of an act in terms so vague that men of common intelligence must necessarily guess at its meaning and differ as to its application violates the first essential of due process of law.}}</ref><ref name="43 Cal.2d 626 "/> and any legal expectation to the contrary would implicate violating the [[vagueness doctrine]] of the [[US Constitution]].<ref name="269 US 385"/>{{refn| The [[overbreadth doctrine]] is also implicated whereby to avoid the risk of legal consequences for using blind intersections for which there is no fair notice of other traffic bringing a prohibition of its use into effect, persons with no alternative route are dissuaded from the liberty of free movement, expression, and to peacefully assemble. Hence the law's effects are thereby far broader than intended or than the U.S. Constitution permits. Furthermore, as insufficient intersectional sight-distance is often often symptomatic of old, urban high-density neighborhoods, with multiple tenant households saturating narrow street parking,—predominately lower social-economic environments—entire classes of people may be unequally discouraged from even leaving their houses. The through-driver is not adversely affected in this regard, by being compelled to slow down as to be able to stop to avoid collision with entering car or pedestrian as required by law. |group="Note"}} It is the duty of the through-driver to slow down<ref name="CDL">{{cite book |title=California Commercial Driver Handbook (2014-2015) |chapter=Section 13: On-Road Driving |chapter-url=https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/pubs/cdl_htm/sec13?projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d&projectid=34cc355c-5dc2-49e1-86d5-ca94968e3e3d |url=https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/wcm/connect/42c566ef-31ac-4df2-a8ed-480619084886/comlhdbk.pdf?MOD=AJPERES |pages=2–19, 13–2 |publisher=California Department of Motor Vehicles |date=2015 |quote=[pg 2-19] 2.6.4 – '''Speed and Distance Ahead[:]''' You should always be able to stop within the distance you can see ahead. Fog, rain, or other conditions may require that you slow down to be able to stop in the distance you can see. ... [pg 13-2]'''13.1.2 – Intersections''' As you approach an intersection: • Check traffic thoroughly in all directions. • '''Decelerate gently.''' • '''Brake smoothly''' and, if necessary, change gears. • If necessary, come to a complete stop (no coasting) behind any stop signs, signals, sidewalks, or stop lines maintaining a safe gap behind any vehicle in front of you. • Your vehicle must not roll forward or backward. Note: Do not enter the intersection if there is insufficient space to clear it. When driving through an intersection: •Check traffic thoroughly in all directions. •'''Decelerate ''and'' yield to any pedestrians and traffic in the intersection.''' •Do not change lanes while proceeding through the intersection. •Keep your hands on the wheel.}}</ref><ref name="106 Cal. App. 2d 294"/><ref name="179 Cal. 349"/><ref name="213 Cal. 644"/> and apply the ACDA principle specifically to the intersection.<ref name="CDLM"/><ref name="189 Cal. 335"/><ref name="175 Cal. 497"/><ref name="22 Cal. App. 2d 636"/><ref name="100 Cal. App. 2d 411"/> See [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Table of detection thresholds|Table of detection thresholds]].
{{hidden begin | expanded = True |toggle = right |title = Technical ACDA Theory of Intersections |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = left |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:1em; |extra2 = font-size:100%; padding-left:1em; }}
When approaching an un-signalized intersection controlled by a [[stop sign]], the assured clear distance ahead is:
:<math> ACDA_{si} = V \left( \sqrt{\frac{2d_i}{a_i}} + t_{pc} \right) </math>
Normal acceleration "{{math|a<sub>i</sub>}}" for a passenger vehicle from a stop up to 20 mph is about 0.15g, with more than 0.3g being difficult to exceed.<ref name="J. Stannard Baker"/> The distance "{{math|d<sub>i</sub>}}" is the sum of the measured [[Stop and yield lines|limit line]] setback distance—which is typically regulated by a [[Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices]], at often between 4 and 30 feet in the United States<ref name="23 CFR 603">{{cite web |url=http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=a2583ef3fa3a41e5b157549f8dd705ab&mc=true&node=pt23.1.655&rgn=div5#se23.1.655_1603 |title=Title 23, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 655.603 |publisher=US Government Publishing Office |quote=The MUTCD approved by the Federal Highway Administrator is the national standard for all traffic control devices installed on any street, highway, or bicycle trail open to public travel in accordance with 23 U.S.C. 109(d) and 402(a)...Where State or other Federal agency MUTCDs or supplements are required, they shall be in substantial conformance with the National MUTCD.}}</ref><ref name="CAMUTCD">{{cite book |chapter-url=http://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/traffops/engineering/mutcd/ca_mutcd2014.htm |title=California MUTCD 2014 |publisher=California Department of Transportation |chapter=3B.16.10 |page=681 |quote=Chapter 3B.16.10: If used, stop and yield lines should be placed a minimum of 4 feet in advance of the nearest crosswalk line at controlled intersections...In the absence of a marked crosswalk, the stop line or yield line should be placed at the desired stopping or yielding point, but should not be placed more than 30 feet or less than 4 feet from the nearest edge of the intersecting traveled way.}}</ref><ref name="CAHDM">{{cite book |title=California Highway Design Manual |publisher=California Department of Transportation |chapter=405.1 |pages=400–14 |year=2012 |chapter-url=http://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/oppd/hdm/hdmtoc.htm |quote=Chapter 405.1: Set back for the driver of the vehicle on the crossroad shall be a minimum of 10 feet plus the shoulder width of the major road but not less than 15 feet.}}</ref>—and the [[crosswalk]], [[Parallel parking|parking lane]], and [[road shoulder]] width. A vehicle accelerating from a stop travels this distance in time {{math| t<sub>i</sub>{{=}}{{radical|{{frac|2d<sub>i</sub>|a<sub>i</sub>}}}}}} while through traffic travels a distance equal to their speed multiplied by that time. The time {{math|t<sub>pc</sub>}}, for the stopped motorist, is the sum of perception time and the time required to actuate an automatic transmission or shift to first gear which is usually between {{math|{{frac|1|2}}}} to one second.<ref name="AASHO"/> {{hidden end}}
====ACDA as a function of horizontal sight distance==== Horizontal clearance is measured from the edge of the traveled way to the bottom of the nearest object, tree trunk or shrub foliage mass face, plant setback, or mature growth.<ref name="AASHTO">{{cite book |title=A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets |edition=6th |year=2011 |publisher=American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials |isbn=978-1560515081 |url=https://bookstore.transportation.org/collection_detail.aspx?ID=110}}</ref><ref name="CDOT"/> Horizontal sight distance is not to be confused with the clear recovery zone which provides hazardous vegetation set-back to allow errant vehicles to regain control, and is exclusive to a mowed and limbed-up forest which can allow adequate sight distance, but unsafe recovery.<ref name="CDOT"/> The height and lateral distance of plants restrict the horizontal sight distance, at times obscuring wildlife which may be spooked by an approaching vehicle and run across the road to escape with their [[herd]].<ref name="deer">{{Cite journal |title = Targeting mitigation efforts: The role of speed limit and road edge clearance for deer–vehicle collisions |doi = 10.1002/jwmg.712 |journal =The Journal of Wildlife Management |date=2014 |volume=78 |issue = 4 |pages=679–688 |quote=speed limit reduction and road edge clearance are both powerful mitigation tools to reduce the number of [[Deer–vehicle collisions]].|last1 = Meisingset |first1 = Erling L |last2 = Loe |first2 = Leif E |last3 = Brekkum |first3 = Øystein |last4 = Mysterud |first4 = Atle }}</ref><ref name="CDOT"/> This principle also applies to approaching vehicles and pedestrians at uncontrolled intersections and to a lesser degree by un-signalized intersections controlled by a [[yield sign]]. Horizontal sight distance "{{math|d<sub>hsd</sub>}}" affects the ACDA because the time {{math|t<sub>i</sub>{{=}}{{sfrac|d<sub>hsd</sub>|V<sub>i</sub>}}}} it takes for an intercepting object, animal, pedestrian, or vehicle with speed "{{math|V<sub>i</sub>}}" to transverse this distance after emerging from the proximate edge of lateral visibility affords a vehicle with speed "{{math|V}}" a clear distance of "{{math|V*t<sub>i</sub>}}." Thus, the assured clear intercept distance "{{math|ACDA<sub>si</sub>}}" is:
:<math> ACDA_{si}=\frac{V d_{hsd}}{V_i} </math>
The faster one drives, the farther down-road an interceptor must be in order to be able to transverse the horizontal sight distance in time to collide, however this says nothing of whether the vehicle can stop by the end of this type of assured clear distance. Equating this distance to the total stopping distance and solving for speed yields one's maximum [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Relation to the basic speed rule|safe speed]] as purely dictated by the horizontal sight distance.
===Dynamic "following" distance=== The ACDA may also be dynamic as to the moving distance past which a motorist can be assured to be able to stay clear of a foreseeable dynamic hazard—such as to maintain a distance as to be able to safely swerve around a bicyclist should he succumb to a fall—without requiring a full stop beforehand, if doing so could be exercised with [[due care]] towards surrounding traffic. Quantitatively this distance is a function of the appropriate time gap and the operating speed: {{math|d<sub>ACDA</sub>{{=}}t<sub>gap</sub>⋅<var>v</var>}}. The assured clear distance ahead rule, rather than being subject to exceptions, is not really intended to apply beyond situations in which a vigilant ordinarily prudent person could or should anticipate.<ref name="75 ALR.3d 327"/> A common way to violate the dynamic ACDA is by [[tailgating]].
===Measurement=== The most accurate way to determine the ACDA is to directly measure it. Whereas this is impractical, [[Geometric design of roads#Profile|sight distance formulas]] can be used with less direct measurements as rough baseline estimates. The [[empirical]] assured clear distance ahead calculated with [[computer vision]], [[range finding]], [[traction control]], and [[Geographic information system|GIS]], such as by properly [[Computer programming|programming]] computer hardware used in [[autonomous cars]], can be recorded to later produce or color baseline ACDA and safe speed maps for accident investigation, traffic engineering, and show disparities between safe speed and 85th percentile "operating" speed.<ref name="computer vision">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/15/magazine/the-dream-life-of-driverless-cars.html |title=Sightlines/The Dream Life of Driverless Cars |author=Geoff Manaugh |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |page=MM68 |date=November 15, 2015 |quote=One of the most significant uses of 3-D scanning in the years to come will not be by humans at all but by autonomous vehicles.}}</ref> Self-driving cars<ref name=":0" /><ref name="rules">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/02/technology/personaltech/google-says-its-not-the-driverless-cars-fault-its-other-drivers.html |title=Google’s Driverless Cars Run Into Problem: Cars With Drivers |author1=Matt Richtel |author2=Conor Dougherty |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |page=A1 |date=September 2, 2015 |quote=Google’s fleet of autonomous test cars is programmed to follow the letter of the law. But it can be tough to get around if you are a stickler for the rules. ... One Google car, in a test in 2009, couldn’t get through a four-way stop because its sensors kept waiting for other (human) drivers to stop completely and let it go. The human drivers kept inching forward, looking for the advantage — paralyzing Google’s robot. ... “It’s always going to follow the rules, I mean, almost to a point where human drivers who get in the car and are like ‘Why is the car doing that?’” said Tom Supple, a Google safety driver during a recent test drive on the streets near Google’s Silicon Valley headquarters. ...the technology, like Google’s car, drives by the book. It leaves what is considered the safe distance between itself and the car ahead. ...Dmitri Dolgov, head of software for Google’s Self-Driving Car Project, said that one thing he had learned from the project was that human drivers needed to be “less idiotic.” ... The laser system mounted on top of the driverless car sensed that a vehicle coming the other direction was approaching the red light at higher-than-safe speeds. The Google car immediately jerked to the right in case it had to avoid a collision. }}</ref> may have a higher safe speed than human driven vehicles for a given ACDA where computer perception-reaction times are nearly instantaneous.
===Discretion=== The Assured Clear Distance Ahead can be subjective to the baseline estimate of a [[ordinary care|reasonable person]] or be predetermined by law. For example, whether one should have reasonably foreseen that a road was not assuredly clear past 75–100 meters because of tractors or livestock which commonly emerge from encroaching blinding vegetation is on occasion dependent on societal experience within the locale. In certain urban environments, a straight, traffic-less, through-street may not necessarily be assuredly clear past the entrance of the nearest [[Geometric design of roads#Effects of insufficient sight distance|visually obstructed intersection]] as law.<ref name="189 Cal. 335"/><ref name="22 Cal. App. 2d 636"/><ref name="139 Cal. App. 2d 65"/><ref name="Human Factors"/> Within the assured clear distance ahead, there is certainty that travel will be free from obstruction which is exclusive of a failure to appreciate a hazard. Collisions generally only occur within one's assured clear distance ahead which are "unavoidable" to them such that they have zero comparative negligence including [[Act of God|legal acts of god]] and abrupt unforeseeably wanton negligence by another party. Hazards which penetrate one's proximate edge of clear visibility and compromise their ACDA generally require evasive action.
Drivers need not and are not required to precisely determine the maximum safe speed from real-time mathematical calculations of sight distances and stopping distances for their particular vehicle.<ref name="83 Cal. App. 2d 377">{{cite court |litigants=Malinson v. Black, 83 Cal. App. 2d 377 |vol=83 |reporter=Official California Appellate Reports, Second Series |opinion=377 |pinpoint= |court=[[California courts of appeal|California Appellate Court]] |publisher=Bancroft-Whitney; LexisNexis |date=January 27, 1948 |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/california/court-of-appeal/2d/83/375.html |accessdate= |quote=It is apparent that plaintiff misjudged the speed of the truck and was mistaken as to his ability to cross Anaheim Street in front of it with safety. However, every mistake of judgment is not negligence, for mistakes are made even in the exercise of ordinary care. [http://www.lexisnexis.com/clients/CACourts/ See Official Reports Online.]}}</ref> Motor vehicle operators of average intelligence<ref name="Holmes">{{cite book |title=The Common Law |author=[[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.]] |publisher=[[Little, Brown and Company]] |date=1881 |page=108,122,123 |chapter=Lecture III—D. Liability for unintended Harm is determined by what would be Blameworthy in Average man |chapter-url=https://archive.org/stream/commonlaw00holmuoft#page/108/mode/2up |quote=The standards of the law are standards of general application. The law takes no account of the infinite varieties of temperament, intellect, and education which make the internal character of a given act so different in different men. ... [Page 122] the averment that the defendant has been guilty of negligence ... that his alleged conduct does not come up to the legal standard. ... the question whether the court or the jury ought to judge of the defendant's conduct is wholly unaffected by the accident, ... it is entirely possible to give a series of hypothetical instructions adapted to every state of facts which it is open to the jury to find. ... the court may still take their opinion as to the standard. ... [page 123] ...supposing a state of facts often repeated in practice, is it to be imagined that the court is to go on leaving the standard to the jury forever? ... if the jury is, on the whole, as fair a tribunal as it is represented to be, the lesson which can be got from that source will be learned.... the court will find ... the conduct complained of usually is or is not blameworthy, ... or '''it will find the jury oscillating to and fro, and will see the necessity of making up its mind for itself.''' There is no reason why any other such question should not be settled, as well as that of liability for stairs with smooth strips of brass upon their edges.|title-link=The Common Law (Holmes) }}</ref><ref name="47 Cal.App.3d 164">{{cite court |litigants=Fox v. City and County of San Francisco, 47 Cal.App.3d 164 |vol=47 |reporter=Official California Appellate Reports, 3rd Series |opinion=164 |pinpoint= |court=[[California courts of appeal|California Appellate Court]] |date=April 14, 1975 |publisher=Bancroft-Whitney; LexisNexis |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/california/court-of-appeal/3d/47/164.html |accessdate= |quote=drivers with mental disabilities are required to exercise the ordinary care required of an adult without such disability. [http://www.lexisnexis.com/clients/CACourts/ See Official Reports Online.]}}</ref> are constantly required to utilize their [[Eye–hand coordination|kinesthetic memory]] in all sorts of driving tasks including every time they brake to a full stop at a stop line in a panoply of conditions.<ref name="156 Cal.App.2d 374"/><ref name="Gibson&Crooks">{{cite journal |title=A Theoretical Field-Analysis of Automobile-Driving |author1=James J. Gibson |author2=Laurence E. Crooks |journal=The American Journal of Psychology |volume=51 |issue=3 |pages=453–471 |date=July 1938 |doi=10.2307/1416145 |issn=0002-9556 |oclc=473102987 |jstor= 1416145 |quote=}}</ref> Like throwing a softball, one does not have to mathematically calculate a trajectory or firing solution in order to hit a target with repeated accuracy. During the earliest stages of [[action learning|learning how to drive]], one develops a memory of when to start braking (how long it takes) from various speeds in order to stop at the limit line.<ref name="Gibson&Crooks"/> While there may be a degree of variance of such skill in seasoned drivers, they generally do not have the discretion in engaging in a behavior such as driving a speed above which no reasonable minds might differ as to whether it is unsafe or that one could come to a stop within the full distance ahead.<ref name="213 Cal. 644"/><ref name="47 Cal.App.3d 164"/>
====Seconds of distance to stop rule====
Drivers and law enforcement alike can apply elementary level arithmetic<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.corestandards.org/assets/CCSSI_Math%20Standards.pdf |title=Common Core State Standard for Mathematics |publisher=Common Core State Standards Initiative |page=27 |quote=See 4th grade math level}}</ref> towards a [[rule of thumb]] to estimate minimal stopping distance in terms of how many seconds of travel ahead at their current speed. For speed "{{math|<var>v</var>}}" in miles per hour, this rule of thumb is as follows:
:::<math>\color{Sepia}{t\approx\frac{v}{20} + 1 \quad \text{(Seconds of distance to stop rule)}}</math>
If this distance is greater than the ACDA, they need to slow down. While most experienced drivers develop a broad [[intuition]] required by everyday braking,<ref name="Gibson&Crooks"/> this rule of thumb can still benefit some to recalibrate expectations for rare hard braking, particularly from high speeds. Additional simple corrections can be made to compensate for the environment and driving ability. Read more about the [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Seconds of distance to stop rule 2|Seconds of Distance to Stop Rule]].
==ACDA Rule specific case generalized to the Basic Speed Law== The ACDA distances are a principal component to be evaluated in the determination of the maximum safe speed (V<sub>BSL</sub>) under the [[Speed limit#Reasonable speed|basic speed law]], without which the maximum safe speed cannot be determined. As mathematical statements are more precise than verbal statements alone,<ref name="Hand rule"/> the relation of the ACDA as a [[subset]] of the basic speed rule for land based vehicles may be objectively quantified as follows:
:<math> V_{BSL}= \begin{cases} \sqrt{(\mu +e)^2 g^2 t_{prt}^2+ 2 (\mu + e) g d_{ACDA_s} } - (\mu+e) g t_{prt}, & \text{if } V_{ACDA_s} \le V_{ACDA_{si1}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si2}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_d} \text{ or } V_{cs} \text{ or } V_{cl}\\ \\ 2 g (\mu + e) (\frac{d_{hsd}}{v_i}-t_{prt}), & \text{if } V_{ACDA_{si1}} < V_{ACDA_s} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si2}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_d} \text{ or } V_{cs} \text{ or } V_{cl}\\ \\ 2 g (\mu + e )\left(\sqrt{\frac{2 d_{sl}}{a_i}}+t_{pc}-t_{prt}\right), & \text{if } V_{ACDA_{si2}} < V_{ACDA_s} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si1}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_d} \text{ or } V_{cs} \text{ or } V_{cl}\\ \\ \frac{d_{ACDA_d}}{t_g}, & \text{if } V_{ACDA_d}< V_{ACDA_s} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si1}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si2}} \text{ or } V_{cs} \text{ or } V_{cl} \\ \\ \sqrt{ \frac{(\mu+e) g r}{1-\mu e}}, & \text{if } V_{cs}<V_{ACDA_s} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si1}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si2}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_d} \text{ or } V_{cl} \\ \\ V_{cl}, & \text{if } V_{cl}< V_{ACDA_s} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si 1}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_{si 2}} \text{ or } V_{ACDA_d} \text{ or } V_{cs} \end{cases}
</math>
The value of the variable "e" is the [[sine]] of the [[angle]] of inclination of the road's [[slope]]. For a level road this value is zero, and for [[Small-angle approximation|small angles]] it approximates the road's percent [[Grade (slope)|grade]] divided by one hundred. :<math> e = \sin(\theta) \approx \theta \approx \tan(\theta) = \frac{\%grade}{100} </math>
{{refn| In most jurisdictions, [[judicial notice]] shall be taken of the [[braking distance#Total stopping distance|total stopping distance]], and such notice is therefore logically and substantively taken of the maximum speed permitted to brake within the stopping distance as applied to the ACDA. The latter is merely the [[inverse function]] of the former. Furthermore, fundamental mathematical relationships are themselves subject to judicial notice.
<math>V_{ACDA(s)}=\sqrt{\mu^2 g^2 t_{prt}^2+ 2 \mu g d_{ACDA_s} } - \mu g t_{prt}</math>
For example, using the <math>\mu=0.7</math> and <math>t_{prt}=1.5</math> values that produced [http://law.lis.virginia.gov/vacode/46.2-880/ Code of Virginia § 46.2-880 Tables of speed and stopping distances], one simply obtains the same velocities that produced the [[braking distance#Total stopping distance|stopping distance]] in the statute:
[[Metric system|Metric]] ([[International System of Units|SI]]) – Speed in [[km/h]] from distance in [[Metre|meters]]: <math>V_{ACDA} \approx \sqrt{1372.3+ 177.8 d_{ACDA} } - 37.0</math>
[[United States customary units|US customary]] – Speed in [[Miles per hour|MPH]] from distance in [[Foot (unit)|feet]]: <math>V_{ACDA} \approx \sqrt{529.8+ 20.9 d_{ACDA} } - 23.0</math> |group="Note" |name="BSL formula example"}}
The maximum velocity permitted by the Assured Clear Distance Ahead is controlling of safe speed (V<sub>BSL</sub>) for only the top and two cases. Safe speed may be greater or less than the actual [[speed limit|legal speed limit]] depending upon the conditions along the road.<ref name="J. Stannard Baker">{{cite book |title=Traffic Accident Investigator's Manual for Police |edition=2 |author=J. Stannard Baker |publisher=The Traffic Institute, Northwestern University |year=1963 |pages=43–48 |lccn=62-20895}} </ref>
{{refn| Safe Speed will be outputted in the same terms as the input units. Entering a distance in feet and an acceleration in terms of feet/s<sup>2</sup> will produce a safe speed in terms of feet/second. To convert to miles per hour, multiply by {{math|{{sfrac|22|15}}}}. Entering distance and acceleration in terms of meters will output a speed in meters per second, which may be converted to kilometers per hour by multiplying by a {{math|{{sfrac|18|5}}}} (or 3.6) factor. |group="Note" |name="Converting to familiar units"}}
See reference [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Derivations|V<sub>BSL</sub> derivations]] for basic physics explanation.
===ACDA: forward line-of-sight=== For the top case, the maximum speed is governed by the assured clear "line-of-sight", as when the "following distance" aft of forward traffic and "steering control" are both adequate. Common examples include when there is no vehicle to be viewed, or when there is a haze or fog that would prevent visualizing a close vehicle in front. This maximum velocity is denoted by the case variable <math>V_{ACDA_s}</math>, the [[coefficient of friction|friction coefficient]] is symbolized by <math>\mu</math>—and itself a function of the [[Treadwear rating|tire type]] and [[road slipperiness|road conditions]], the distance <math>d_{ACDA_s}</math> is the static ACDA, the constant <math>g</math> is the [[Gravity of Earth|acceleration of gravity]], and interval <math>t_{prt}</math> is the [[Mental chronometry|perception-reaction time]]—usually between 1.0 and 2.5 seconds.<ref name="Taoka">{{cite journal |last1=Taoka |first1=George T. |title=Brake Reaction Times of Unalerted Drivers |journal=ITE Journal |volume=59 |issue=3 |pages= 19–21 |date=March 1989 |url=http://www.ite.org/membersonly/itejournal/pdf/jca89a19.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Olsen&Sivak">{{cite journal |title=Perception-response time to unexpected roadway hazards |author1=Paul L. Olson |author2=Michael Sivak |journal=Human Factors |volume=28 |issue=1 |pages=91–96 |date=February 1986 |doi= 10.1177/001872088602800110 |pmid=3710489 |url=http://hfs.sagepub.com/content/28/1/91.full.pdf |quote=Perception-response (PR) time, the time from the first sighting of an obstacle until the driver applies the brakes, is an important component of stopping sight distance. ... The results indicate a 95th percentile PR time of about 1.6 s for both age groups.}}</ref>
See [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Table of ACDA: forward line-of-sight|Table of safe speed versus forward line-of-sight]]
===ACDA: horizontal line-of-sight=== The second case describes the relationship of horizontal sight distance on safe speed. It is the maximum speed at which a vehicle can come to a full stop before an object, with speed V<sub>i</sub>, can intercept after having emerged and traveled across the horizontal sight distance "d<sub>hsd</sub>." Urban and residential areas have horizontal sight distances that tend to be closely obstructed by parked cars, utility poles, street furnishing, fencing, signage, and landscaping, but have slower intercepting speeds of children, pedestrians, backing cars, and domestic animals. These interceptors combined with dense usage results in collisions that are more probable and much more likely to inflict harm to an outside human life. In rural areas, swift-moving spooked wildlife such as [[deer]],<ref name="deer"/> [[elk]], [[Moose#Vehicle collisions|moose]], and [[pronghorn|antelope]] are more likely to intercept a roadway at over 30 mph (48 kph). Wildlife will frequently transit across a road before a full stop is necessary, however collisions with large [[Game (hunting)|game]] are foreseeably lethal, and a driver generally has a duty not to harm his or her passengers. The foreseeable intercept speed or defectively designed horizontal sight distance may vary "reasonably" with [[judicial discretion]].
See [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Table of ACDA: horizontal line-of-sight|Table of safe speed versus horizontal line-of-sight]]
===ACDA: intersectional setback=== This third case regards safe speed around un-signalized intersections where a driver on an uncontrolled through street has a duty to slow down in crossing an intersection and permit [[stop sign|controlled]] drivers to be able pass through the intersection without danger of collision.<ref name="213 Cal. 644">{{cite court |litigants=Page v. Mazzei, 213 Cal. 644 |vol=213 |reporter=Official California Reports |opinion=644 |pinpoint= |court=[[Supreme Court of California]] |date=21 September 1931 |url=https://casetext.com/case/page-v-mazzei |accessdate= |quote=Where a car has actually entered an intersection before the other approaches it, the driver of the first car has the right to assume that he will be given the right of way and be permitted to pass through the intersection without danger of collision. He has a right to assume that the driver of the other car will obey the law, slow down, and yield the right of way, if slowing down be necessary to prevent a collision. ( Keyes v. Hawley, 100 Cal. App. 53, 60 [279 Pac. 674].) Nor is a plaintiff required to yield the right of way to one a considerable distance away whose duty it is to slow down in crossing an intersection. See [http://www.lexisnexis.com/clients/CACourts/ Official Reports Opinions Online]}}</ref> The driver on the through street must anticipate and hence not approach at an unsafe speed which would prevent another driver from being able to enter while traffic was some distance away, or would be unsafe to a driver who has already established control of the intersection under a prudent acceleration a<sub>i</sub>, from a stop at a limit line a distance d<sub>sl</sub> away.<ref name=AASHO>{{cite book |title=A Policy on Geometric Design of Rural Highways |publisher=American Association of State Highway and Traffic Officials |date=1969 |page=394 |quote=Where an obstruction, which cannot be removed except at prohibitive cost, fixes the vertices of the sight triangle at points that are less than the safe stopping distances from the intersection, vehicles may be brought to a stop (after sighting other vehicles on the intersecting road) only if they are traveling at a speed appropriate to the available sight distance.}}</ref>
===ACDA: following distance=== The pedantic fourth case applies when the dynamic ACDA "following distance" (d<sub>ACDA<sub>d</sub></sub>) is less than the static ACDA "line-of-sight" distance (d<sub>ACDA<sub>s</sub></sub>). A classic instance of this occurs when, from a visibility perspective, it would be safe to drive much faster were it not for a slower-moving vehicle ahead. As such, the dynamic ACDA is governing the basic speed rule, because in maintaining this distance, one cannot drive at a faster speed than that matching the forward vehicle. The "time gap" t<sub>g</sub> or "time cushion" is the time required to travel the dynamic ACDA or "following distance" at the [[operating speed]]. Circumstances depending, this cushion might be manifested as a [[two-second rule]] or three-second rule.
See [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Table of following distances|Table of 2-second following distances]]
===Critical speed=== In the fifth case, critical speed V<sub>cs</sub> applies when road curvature is the factor limiting safe speed. A vehicle which exceeds this speed will [[slip angle|slide]] out of its lane. Critical speed is a function of curve [[radius]] "r," [[superelevation]] or banking "e," and friction coefficient "μ;"<ref name="J. Stannard Baker"/> the constant "g" again is the acceleration of gravity. However, most motorists will not tolerate a lateral acceleration exceeding 0.3g (μ=0.3) above which many will panic.<ref name="Glennon-Hill">{{cite book |title=Roadway Safety and Tort Liability |edition=2 |publisher=Lawyers & Judges Publishing Company, Inc. |author1=John C. Glennon |author2=Paul F. Hill |page=293 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmqrDaOwn3kC&pg=PA293&lpg|isbn=9781930056947 |year=2004 }}</ref> Hence, critical speed may not resemble loss of control speed.<ref name="Glennon-Hill"/> Attenuated "side" friction coefficients are often used for computing critical speed.<ref name="CDOT">{{cite book |url=http://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/oppd/hdm/hdmtoc.htm |title=Highway Design Manual |chapter=Geometric Design And Structure Standards |chapter-url=http://www.dot.ca.gov/hq/oppd/hdm/pdf/english/chp0200.pdf |pages=200–1, 200–2, 200–3, 200–4, 200–7, 200–10, 200–11, 200–20 |publisher=California Department of Transportation}}</ref> The formula is frequently approximated without the denominator for low angle banking which may be suitable for nearly all situations except the tightest radius of highway onramps.<ref name="CDOT"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cadzone.com/manuals/crash-crime/crash9/Program_Commands/recon_menu/Critical_Speed_calc.htm |title=Critical Speed Calculator |publisher=The CAD Zone. Inc. |date=2015}}</ref> The principle of critical speed is often applied to the problem of [[traffic calming]], where curvature is both used to govern maximum road speed, and used in [[traffic circles]] as a device to force drivers to obey their [[Duty of care|duty]] to slow down when approaching an intersection.<ref name="106 Cal. App. 2d 294"/><ref name="179 Cal. 349"/>
See [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Table of critical speeds|Table of curvatures and critical speeds]]
===Surface control=== The bottom case is invoked when the maximum velocity for surface control V<sub>cl</sub> is otherwise reached. Steering control is independent from any concept of clear distance ahead. If a vehicle cannot be controlled so as to safely remain within its lane above a certain speed and circumstance, then it is irrelevant how assuredly clear the distance is ahead. Using the example of the previous case, the safe speed on a curve may be such that a driver experiences a lateral acceleration of less than 0.3g despite that the vehicle may not slide until it experiences 0.8g. [[Speed wobble]], [[aquaplaning|hydroplaning]], [[roll center]], [[fishtailing]], [[jackknifing|jackknife]] tendencies, [[potholes]], [[washboarding]], [[frost heaving]],<ref name="Montana v. Stanko">{{cite court |litigants=State of Montana v. Rudy Stanko |vol= |reporter= |opinion= |pinpoint= |court=[[Supreme Court of Montana]] |date=23 December 1998 |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/mt-supreme-court/1110919.html |accessdate=February 2016 |quote=the road was narrow, there were hills and curves which presented some degree of obstruction to the view ahead, and there was an occasional frost heave on the surface of the road. A reasonable speed under these circumstances would require a calculation of sight distances and stopping distances for the particular vehicle. ...The arresting officer described in detail the roadway where Stanko was operating his vehicle at 85 miles per hour. The roadway was very narrow with no shoulders. There were frost heaves on the road which caused the officer's vehicle to bounce. The highway had steep hills, sharp curves, and multiple no-passing zones. There were numerous ranch and field access roads in the area which ranchers use for bringing hay to their cattle. The officer testified that at 85 miles per hour, there was no way for Stanko to stop in the event there had been an obstruction on the road beyond the crest of a hill. In the officer's judgment, driving a vehicle at the speed of 85 miles per hour on the stretch of road in question posed a danger to the rest of the driving public.}}</ref> and [[tire speed rating]] are other factors limiting V<sub>cl</sub>.
==Safe speed== Safe speed is the maximum speed permitted by the basic speed law and negligence doctrine. Safe speed is not the same as the 85 percentile [[operating speed]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/speedmgt/ref_mats/fhwasa10001/ |title=Speed Concepts: Informational Guide |publisher=US Department of Transportation |quote='''Operating speed''' - the speeds at which vehicles are observed operating during free flow conditions. Free flow speeds are those observed from vehicles whose operations are unimpeded by traffic control devices (e.g., traffic signals) or by other vehicles in the traffic stream. The 85th percentile of the distribution of observed speeds is the most frequently used measure of the operating speed.}}</ref> used by traffic engineers in establishing speed zones.<ref name="J. Stannard Baker"/><ref name="23 CFR 603"/><ref name="23 CFR 625"/><ref name="US MUTCD"/> Fog, snow, or ice can create conditions where most people drive too fast, and [[Multiple-vehicle collision|chain reaction accidents]] in such conditions are examples of where large groups of drivers collided because they failed to reduce speed for the conditions.<ref name="J. Stannard Baker"/><ref name="mass crash">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/sep/05/car-pileup-sheppey-bridge-kent |title='All you could hear was cars crashing': 120-car pile-up on Sheppey bridge |author=Maev Kennedy |date=September 6, 2013 |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |quote=the probable cause of the accident was "stupid driving". ... "It's really bad to travel too close to the car in front in good conditions and if you do it in foggy conditions it's an absolute recipe for disaster."}}</ref> The speeds at which most people drive can only be a very rough guide to safe speed,<ref name="J. Stannard Baker"/> and an illegal or negligent custom or practice is not in itself excusable.<ref name="60 Cal. App. 764">{{cite court |litigants=Reinders v. Olsen, 60 Cal. App. 764 |vol=60 |reporter=California Appellate Reports |opinion=764 |court=California Appellate Court |date=February 13, 1923 |url=https://casetext.com/case/reinders-v-olsen |accessdate= |quote=the fact of knowledge on the part of plaintiff relating to the "custom" or, rather, practice, of automobile drivers ... no such practice could be binding on plaintiff so as to excuse defendant from violating the statute in that regard, provided that such act was the proximate cause of the accident. See [http://www.lexisnexis.com/clients/CACourts/ Official Reports Opinions]}}</ref><ref name="Holmes"/><ref name="McCormick et al.">{{cite journal |title=Comparative perceptions of driver ability–A confirmation and expansion |author1=Iain A. McCormick |author2=Frank H. Walkey |author3=Dianne E. Green |journal=[[Accident Analysis & Prevention]] |volume=18 |number=3 |pages=205–208 |date=June 1986 |doi=10.1016/0001-4575(86)90004-7 |issn=0001-4575 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0001457586900047 |quote=a substantial majority of drivers, up to 80%, would rate themselves above average on a number of important characteristics}}</ref><ref name="275 U.S. 66"/> Safe speed approximates the inferred [[design speed]] adjusted for environmental alterations and vehicle and person specific factors when V<sub>ACDA<sub>s</sub></sub> is the limiting factor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/speedmgt/ref_mats/fhwasa10001/ |title=Speed Concepts: Informational Guide |publisher=US Department of Transportation |quote='''Inferred design speed''' – the maximum speed for which all critical design-speed-related criteria are met at a particular location.}}</ref> The [[Solomon curve]] concept can create an [[approach-avoidance conflict]] within the driver who wishes neither to drive faster than is lawful and the conditions allow nor have an unsafe speed discrepancy between other vehicles on the road; it is never legal to go faster than the speed limit, and unilaterally reducing the risk of the latter can lead to a mass crash caused by the former.<ref name="mass crash"/> <!--Driving too fast for conditions more dangerous that exceeding posted speed limit https://crashstats.nhtsa.dot.gov/Api/Public/ViewPublication/811090 https://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/speedmgt/ref_mats/fhwasa10001/-->
===Relationship of posted speed limits to the explicitness of driver care standard=== [[File:2005 winter road dipped beam.jpg|thumb|Distance seen with [[ECE Regulations|ECE]] light by night]]
Many people are challenged by the concept of ''unsafe speed'' because they find it vague and arbitrary.<ref name="void for vagueness"/> It is well known that people instead resolve such challenges by [[attribute substitution]],<ref name="kahneman_aer">{{cite journal |last=Kahneman |first=Daniel |date=December 2003 |title=Maps of Bounded Rationality: Psychology for Behavioral Economics |journal= American Economic Review |volume=93 |issue=5 |pages=1449–1475 |doi=10.1257/000282803322655392 |issn=0002-8282 |citeseerx=10.1.1.194.6554 }}</ref> which in this case can mean simply emulating the behaviors of others. In accord with the [[cultural theory of risk]], indeed a substantial part of a driver's [[risk perception]] comes from comparing their contemplated conduct to the behavior of others; this includes the safeness of a given speed, notwithstanding the actual risk. As a result of this uncorrected vagueness, group behavior can often be in opposition to safe speed and still be governing a hazardous posted speed limit. By Federal law, posted speed limits are generally within 5 mph of the 85th-percentile speed of free-flowing traffic.<ref name="AASHTO"/><ref name="23 CFR 603"/><ref name="23 CFR 625">{{cite web |title=Title 23 Code of Federal Regulations, Part 625.4 |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/23/625.4 |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office |quote=}}</ref><ref name="US MUTCD">{{cite book |title=Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD)|url=http://mutcd.fhwa.dot.gov/ |chapter=2009 Edition Chapter 2B. Regulatory Signs, Barricades, and Gates |chapter-url=http://mutcd.fhwa.dot.gov/htm/2009r1r2/part2/part2b.htm |publisher=Federal Highway Administration |quote=[Page 21] Sect.1A.13 —214. '''Speed'''—speed is defined based on the following classifications: (a) '''Average Speed'''—the summation of the instantaneous or spot-measured speeds at a specific location of vehicles divided by the number of vehicles observed. (b) '''Design Speed'''—a selected speed used to determine the various geometric design features of a roadway. (c) '''85th-Percentile Speed'''—the speed at or below which 85 percent of the motor vehicles travel. (d) '''Operating Speed'''—a speed at which a typical vehicle or the overall traffic operates. Operating speed might be defined with speed values such as the average, pace, or 85th-percentile speeds. (e) '''Pace'''—the 10 mph speed range representing the speeds of the largest percentage of vehicles in the traffic stream. [page 58] Section 2B.13 Speed Limit Sign (R2-1) Standard: 01 Speed zones (other than statutory speed limits) shall only be established on the basis of an engineering study that has been performed in accordance with traffic engineering practices. The engineering study shall include an analysis of the current speed distribution of free-flowing vehicles. ...12 '''When a speed limit within a speed zone is posted, it should be within 5 mph of the 85th-percentile speed of free-flowing traffic'''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=National Committee on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (NCUTCD) |url=http://www.ncutcd.org/rulesroad042013.shtml |access-date=2016-02-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305153725/http://www.ncutcd.org/rulesroad042013.shtml |archive-date=2016-03-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Functionality, this amounts to citizens "voting" a street's speed limit with their gas pedal from the influence of [[groupshift]]. As people generally follow explicit rules all the time of which they do not agree, it is often simply a jurisdiction's failure in their law to sufficiently quantify and disseminate fair notice of an explicit standard of care, such as the ACDA rule. Most DMV driver manuals teach the practice, but far fewer states explicitly back it up in their actual statutes and law enforcement.<ref name="CDLM"/><ref name="CA Handbook"/><ref name="AK Handbook"/><ref name="NC Handbook"/> If drivers were mindful of the ACDA, the ''operating speed'' would by definition not exceed the ''inferred design speed''.<ref name="AASHTO"/><ref name="US MUTCD"/> In some cases, police focused on driving while "influenced," pull over slower [[quartile]] sober night-time drivers moving no faster than they can stop within the radius of their headlights;<ref name="CDLM"/> this discourages adjusting speed downward from anything but the posted "maximum speed" permitted by law—which is determined as previously described. It is often unsafe or illegal to drive in excess of 40-50 mph at night.<ref name="AAA headlights"/><ref name="NHTSA Night&Day"/><ref name="236 Cal. App. 2d 555"/><ref name="MTSpeedLaw">{{cite web |title=61-8-303(1)(b)&(3) - Speed restrictions |url=https://leg.mt.gov/bills/mca/title_0610/chapter_0080/part_0030/section_0030/0610-0080-0030-0030.html |website=Montana Code Annotated |publisher=[[State of Montana]] |accessdate=4 July 2018 |quote=the speed limit for vehicles traveling...on any other public highway of this state is 70 miles an hour during the '''daytime''' and 65 miles an hour during the '''nighttime'''...Subject to the maximum speed limits set forth [above] a person shall operate a vehicle in a careful and prudent manner and at a reduced rate of speed no greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions existing at the point of operation, taking into account the amount and character of traffic, '''visibility''', weather, and roadway conditions.}}</ref><ref name="Leibowitz&Herschel"/><ref name="245 Mich. 88"/>

=="Assurance" beyond proximate edge of clear visibility as transference of liability== A general principle in [[Legal liability|liability]] doctrine is than an accident which would not have occurred except for the action or inaction of some person or entity contrary to a [[legal duty|duty]] such as the exercise of [[ordinary care|proper care]] was the result of [[negligence]]. The liability [[Sample space|space]] from which one can recover<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=civ&group=03001-04000&file=3333-3343.7 |title=CA Civil Code §3333 |publisher=The State of California |quote=For the breach of an obligation not arising from contract, the measure of damages, except where otherwise expressly provided by this Code, is the amount which will compensate for all the detriment proximately caused thereby, whether it could have been anticipated or not. |access-date=2015-12-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115055251/http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=civ&group=03001-04000&file=3333-3343.7# |archive-date=2016-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> is typically, themselves, other parties, or nobody.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Cordova v. Ford, 46 Cal. App. 2d 180 |vol=46 |reporter=California Appellate Reports, Second Series |opinion=180 |pinpoint= |court=[[California courts of appeal|California Appellate Court]] |date=7 November 1966 |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/california/calapp2d/246/180.html |accessdate=27 July 2013 |quote="All courts are agreed that the mere fact of a collision of two automobiles gives rise to no inference of negligence against either driver in an action brought by the other. ...When a vehicle operated by '''A''' collides with a vehicle operated by '''B''', there are four possibilities. '''A''' alone was negligent; '''B''' alone was negligent; '''both''' were negligent; or '''neither.''' Of these four only the first will result in liability of '''A''' to '''B'''. The bare fact of a collision affords no basis on which to conclude that it is the preponderant probability. '''The odds are against it.'''" }} See [http://courts.ca.gov/opinions-slip.htm Official Reports Opinions Online]</ref> Jurisdictional exceptions permitting one to legally take "assurance" that the distance will be clear beyond the proximate edge of clear visibility and choose such a speed accordingly, transfers classic common law liability from that driver for his or her "blind" actions. This duty to assure clear distance ahead is inevitably transferred, as an [[externality]] to everybody or thing else who must instead warn the driver, such as the government, its road engineers, and maintainers.<ref name="22 Cal.2d 111">{{cite court |litigants=Peri v. L. A. Junction Railway, 22 Cal.2d 111 |vol=22 |reporter=Official California Reports, Second Series |opinion=111 |pinpoint= |court=[[Supreme Court of California]] |publisher=Bancroft-Whitney; LexisNexis |date=3 May 1943 |url=http://scocal.stanford.edu/opinion/peri-v-l-junction-railway-25708 |accessdate= |quote=Today it is a matter of common knowledge that automobiles are driven at night on our great, wide, straight highways at speeds which do not allow adequate time or space in which to stop for unusual objects such as freight trains completely obstructing the highway unless some warning of the possible or probable presence thereof is given, especially where, as in the case of such trains, the bodies of the cars are apt to be above the direct beams of the automobile lights which the law requires to be projected below 42 inches at 75 feet from the vehicle. Recognizing this, our counties and state highway department place conspicuous warnings of all variations from the normal road. Drivers of ordinary prudence have grown to rely on the presence of such warnings. See [http://courts.ca.gov/opinions-slip.htm Official Reports Opinions Online]}}</ref><ref name="Kenworthy"/><ref name="38 Cal.App.4th 1187">{{cite court |litigants=Chowdhury v. City of Los Angeles, 38 Cal.App.4th 1187 |vol=38 |reporter=Official California Appellate Reports, 4th Series |opinion=1187 |court=[[California courts of appeal|California Appellate Court]] |publisher=Bancroft-Whitney; LexisNexis |date=September 5, 1995 |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/california/court-of-appeal/4th/38/1187.html |accessdate=February 2016 |quote="A public entity does not create a dangerous condition on its property ‘merely because of the failure to provide regulatory traffic control signals, stop signs, yield right-of-way signs, or speed restriction signs . . . .’ (§ 830.4.) If, on the other hand, the government installs traffic signals and invites the public to justifiably rely on them, liability will attach if the signals malfunction, confusing or misleading motorists, and causing an accident to occur. See [http://courts.ca.gov/opinions-slip.htm Official Reports Opinions Online]}}</ref>
As it is generally probable and [[Proximate cause#Foreseeability|foreseeable]] that, chance will permit, and at some point there will be an obstruction beyond some driver's line of sight, such an entitlement challenges centuries<ref name="common law2"/><ref name="common law"/> of [[precedent]] in negligence doctrine in addition to posing difficult policy and engineering challenges. It also violates the [[calculus of negligence]]<ref name="Hand rule"/> because speed is an inherent factor in vehicular accidents which are a leading cause of priceless life loss<ref name="Traffic Safety Facts"/><ref name="Harvard"/><ref name="Heinrich's Law"/><ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/17/business/economy/17regulation.html |title=As U.S. Agencies Put More Value on a Life, Businesses Fret |author=Binyamin Appelbaum |date=February 16, 2011 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |quote=The Environmental Protection Agency set the value of a life at $9.1 million...}}</ref><ref name="cost-benefit">{{cite web |url=http://www.theglobalist.com/the-cost-of-a-human-life-statistically-speaking/ |title=The Cost of a Human Life, Statistically Speaking |author=Frank Partnoy |date=July 21, 2012 |website=The Globalist |quote=when the U.S. government permitted states to raise the speed limit from 55 to 65 miles per hour, many states did so, and drivers saved time by driving about two miles per hour faster on average. However, fatality rates rose by about one-third. Overall, people in the United States saved about 125,000 hours of driving [or about $1.5 million] per lost life. ... researchers have reached a consensus that $1.5 million is much too low [to trade-off for a life]. ... The Environmental Protection Agency set the value of a human life at $9.1 million. Meanwhile, the Food and Drug Administration put it at $7.9 million...}}</ref><ref name="Human Factors"/> and lawsuits, and the burden of a precautions speed is radically lower than the former.<ref name="cost-benefit"/>
The [[assumption of risk]] resulting from the unsafe activity of driving faster than one can stop within one's vision, does not depend ''ex post facto'' on what you happened to hit, for which by nature you could not have known; it could have been a moose or a luxury car. Furthermore, modern times still provide no [[legal remedies]] for [[Darwin Awards|Darwinian misfortune]] upon the entire class of unwarnable accidents where drivers and their passengers would not have collided into the likes of a moose,<ref name="deer"/> livestock,<ref name="CVC 21759"/> fallen tree, rock, jetsam, horse-drawn vehicle,<ref name="CVC 21759"/> stalled vehicle,<ref name="183 So. 2d 68">{{cite court |litigants=Self v. As a rule, when a following vehicle collides with the rear of the lead car, the following driver is considered to be at fault.}}</ref> school bus, garbage truck, mail carrier, snowplow, washout, snow drift, or slid off the road, were it not for their decisions to drive faster than dictated by the assured clear distance ahead. Regardless of what behavior an authority might encourage by fabricating new rights, it remains timeless that constituents cannot sue the wind for causing a wreck when it inevitably violates a "modern right to drive faster than permitted by the ACDA" by failing to warning them it knocked down a tree in a forest with lots of trees which all eventually fall down. In this specific regard, jurisdictions which grant drivers the [[liberty]] to be fools from their own folly, are also condoning the [[collateral damage]] and life loss which is expected to occur. Moreover, modern life-entrusting consumers of [[taxi|driving services]] and [[driver-less cars]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Le Vine|first=Scott|last2=Liu|first2=Xiaobo|last3=Zheng|first3=Fangfang|last4=Polak|first4=John|date=2016-01-01|title=Automated cars: Queue discharge at signalized intersections with 'Assured-Clear-Distance-Ahead' driving strategies|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0968090X15004052|journal=Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies|volume=62|pages=35–54|doi=10.1016/j.trc.2015.11.005}}</ref> who suffer such caused injury are left without legal remedy for foreseeable outcome of imprudent speed; this in-turn unnecessarily transfers a substantive portion of the ACDA liability [[Sample space|space]] into [[act of god]], [[Federal Tort Claims Act|government claims]], [[strict liability]], or other [[verdict|findings]] from [[legal fiction]] which the justice system generally abhors. What modern times are changing is that one may assure the distance is clear ahead virtually through the [[Internet of Things]], as smart cars connect to get information from smart highways or pass what they see ahead or measure to traffic behind.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.its.dot.gov/landing/cv_pilots.htm |title=Connected Vehicle Pilot Program |publisher=US Department of Transportation |quote=The U.S. DOT connected vehicle research program is a multimodal initiative that aims to enable safe, interoperable networked wireless communications among vehicles, infrastructure, and personal communications devices.}}</ref> A fundamental corollary of the ACDA rule is that technology, expectations, and desires may modernize, but the laws of physics can not and do not.<ref name="Nixon">{{cite journal |author=[[Richard M. Allowing one to drive faster than their vision permits them to safely stop, results in there being no core [[standard of care]] regarding safe speed making unsafe speed laws [[void for vagueness]].<ref name="1998 MT 321"/> The ACDA minimum standard gives fair notice of what conduct is prohibited, and people of ordinary intelligence can apply their braking experience or the [[Assured Clear Distance Ahead#Seconds of distance to stop rule|seconds of distance to stop rule]] to the distance they can see;<ref name="Gibson&Crooks"/> once one is allowed to cruise-on without control beyond the edge of visibility, there is little consensus on what arbitrary speed is unsafe, or what to assume of the vague conditions there-past.<ref name="void for vagueness">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/25/us/montana-s-speed-limit-of-mph-is-overturned-as-too-vague.html |title=Montana's Speed Limit of ?? To be able to guarantee "assurance" beyond proximate edge of clear visibility, in doing so exempting ACDA duty, a road must be designed and maintained such that there is not a chance of obstruction in one's lane beyond the proximate edge of clear visibility. A road's vertical [[Geometric design of roads#Profile|profile]] must be assured to have such a curvature as not to hide hazards close behind its crests. [[Discretion]] for drivers and pedestrians to enter onto a potentially occupied lane from a side street must be assuredly eliminated such as with fences, merge lanes, or signalized access. There must also be an assurance of no opportunity for animals and debris to enter from side lots, and that there are continuous multi-hourly maintenance [[highway patrol|patrols]] performed. Furthermore, such road sections must be distinguished from other roads so that the driver could clearly and immediately know when he or she may or may not take such extended "assurance." Few roads might meet these requirements except some of the highest functional classification [[controlled-access highways]] such as [[freeways]] and [[autobahn]]s.<ref name="FHWA"/>
Even if such criteria are met, the law must also exempt driver liability for maintaining clear distance ahead. In most democracies, such liability for failures of the distance to remain clear beyond line of sight would ultimately be transferred to its taxpayers.<ref name="Kenworthy"/> This only generally occurs when governments have been tasked by constituents or their courts to take the responsibly to design and maintain roadways that "assure" the distance will be clear beyond the proximate edge of clear visibility. Pressures to make such changes may arise from cultural [[Wikibooks:Professionalism/Diane Vaughan and the normalization of deviance|normalization of deviance]] and unnecessary risk, misunderstanding the purpose of the road [[functional classification]] system, underestimation of increased risk, and reclamation of commute time.<ref name="FHWA"/>
One of the greatest difficulties created by such an extension of the ACDA is the frequency at which roads reduce their [[functional classification]]<ref name="FHWA"/> unbeknownst to drivers who continue unaware they have lost this extended "assurance" or don't understand the difference. ==Derivations==
===Case 1: Safe speed as a function of forward line-of-sight===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of ACDA 1 |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }}
[[File:Free body.svg|thumb|Forces on a vehicle skidding down a grade of angle ''θ''.]]
Starting with [[Newton's laws of motion#Newton's Second law|Newton's Second Law of Motion]] and the Laws of [[Friction]]:
:<math> F_\text{total} = F_\text{friction} + F_\text{gravity} \sin{\theta} </math>
:<math> F_\text{total} = \mu F_\text{normal} + m g \sin{\theta} </math>
:<math> F_\text{total} = \mu m g \cos{\theta} + m g \sin{\theta} </math>
Equating the net [[force]] to [[mass]] times [[acceleration]]:
:<math> F_\text{total}= m a </math>
:<math> \mu m g \cos{\theta} + m g \sin{\theta} = m a </math>
:<math> a = g(\mu \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta}) </math>
Invoking the [[Equations of motion#Uniform acceleration|equations of motion]] and substituting acceleration:
:<math> d = \frac{v^2}{ 2 a} </math> :<math> d = \frac{v^2}{ 2 g(\mu \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta})} </math>
[[Small-angle approximation]]:
:<math> \sin{\theta} \approx \theta </math> :<math> \cos{\theta} \approx 1 - \frac {\theta^2}{2} </math>
Substituting the small angle approximations, and exploiting that the product of a small angle squared, in radians, with the friction coefficient, θ<sup>2</sup>μ, is insignificant (for a steep 20% slope and a good friction coef. of 0.8, this equals (.2)<sup>2</sup>x0.8≈0.03):
:<math> d \approx \frac{v^2}{ 2 g[\mu (1 - \frac {\theta^2}{2} ) + \theta]} \approx \frac{v^2}{ 2 g(\mu + \theta)}</math>
Now, the total stopping distance is the sum of the braking and perception-reaction distances:
:<math> d_\text{total} = d_\text{braking} + d_\text{perception-reaction} </math>
:<math> d_\text{total} \approx \frac{v^2}{ 2 g(\mu + \theta)} + v t_{pr} </math>
Isolating zero as preparation to solve for velocity:
:<math> \frac{1}{2 g (\mu + \theta)} v^2 + v t_{prt} - d_\text{total} \approx 0 </math>
[[Completing the square]] or invoking the [[quadratic formula]] to find the solution:
:<math> v \approx \sqrt{(\mu + \theta)^2 g^2 t_{prt}^2+ 2 (\mu + \theta) g d_\text{total} } - ( \mu + \theta ) g t_{prt} </math>
Use [[small-angle approximation]] to obtain a more field-able version of the above solution in terms of percent [[Grade (slope)|grade]]/100 "[[superelevation|e]]" instead of an angle θ in radians:
:<math> \theta \approx \tan(\theta) = \frac{\%grade}{100} </math>
Substituting the angle as described produces the form of the formula of case 1 ():
:<math> V_{BSL1} \approx \sqrt{(\mu + e)^2 g^2 t_{prt}^2+ 2 (\mu + e) g d_{ACDA} } - (\mu+e) g t_{prt} </math>
The Basic Speed Law constrains the Assured Clear Distance Ahead to the total stopping distance, and the small angle value of [[Grade (slope)|road grades]] approximates the [[superelevation]] "e."
Many roadways are level, in which case the small angle approximations or superelevation may be dropped altogether: :<math> V_{BSL1} = \sqrt{\mu^2 g^2 t_{prt}^2+ 2 \mu g d_{ACDA} } - \mu g t_{prt} </math>
''This model ignores the effects of [[air drag]], [[rolling resistance]], [[Lift (force)|lift]], and [[Theory of relativity|relativity]] as a vehicle's great [[momentum]] and [[weight]] dominate these factors; they increase the complexity of the formulas while insubstantially changing the outcomes in practically all driving situations except ultra-low-mass [[bicycles]] stopping from inherently dangerously high speeds; usability to the layman and conformance with current standard engineering assumptions<ref name="AASHTO"/><ref name="VA Table"/> is the objective and a vehicle's [http://hpwizard.com/aerodynamics.html lift factor] is often inaccessible. Learn a [[Horizontal plane|level]] ground model with most of those effects [http://hpwizard.com/braking.html#stopping-distance here] or read about the [[automobile drag coefficient]].'' {{hidden end}}
===Case 2: Safe speed as a function of horizontal line-of-sight===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of ACDA 2 |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }}
The time required for an obstruction with speed v<sub>i</sub> to transect the horizontal sight distance d<sub>i</sub>:
:<math> t = \frac{d_i}{v_i} </math>
The time required to travel down a road at speed v to said obstruction of distance d away:
:<math> t= \frac{d}{v} </math>
Equating the two times:
:<math> \frac{d}{v} = \frac{d_i}{v_i} </math>
Solving for this distance: :<math> d=\frac{v d_{i}}{v_i} </math>
Equating this to the total stopping distance, which is the sum of braking and perception-reaction distances: :<math> \frac{v d_{i}}{v_i} = \frac{v^2}{2 g (\mu + e)} + v t_{prt} </math>
Isolating zero, and factoring out a v: :<math> v \left[ \frac{v}{2 g (\mu + e)} + \left(t_{prt} - \frac{ d_{i}}{v_i}\right) \right] = 0 </math>
Solving for the non-trivial case (or may distribute v in equation above and apply quadratic formula for same result): :<math> \frac{v}{2 g (\mu + e)} + (t_{prt} - \frac{ d_{i}}{v_i}) = 0 </math>
The solution to the above equation, which provides the maximum safe speed as a function of horizontal sight distance, intercept velocity, and road-tire friction coefficient: :<math> v = 2 g (\mu + e) ( \frac{ d_{i}}{v_i} - t_{prt}) </math>
{{hidden end}}
===Case 3: Safe speed as a function of intersectional setback===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of ACDA 3 |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }}
The time required for a vehicle to enter a controlled intersection from a stop is the sum of the perception time (t<sub>p</sub>), the time required to actuate an automatic transmission or shift to first gear (t<sub>c</sub>), and the time to accelerate and enter or traverse the road (t<sub>a</sub>). The sum of the first two quantities is t<sub>pc</sub>.
:<math> t= t_p + t_c + t_a = t_{pc} + t_a </math>
The time required for a vehicle entering with acceleration a<sub>i</sub> to transect the sum of the setback and shoulder distances d<sub>i</sub> under uniform acceleration a<sub>i</sub> from a stop via the [[Equations of motion#Constant linear acceleration: collinear vectors|equations of motion]]:
:<math> t_a =\sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } </math>
The time required to travel down a road at speed v to said obstruction of distance d away:
:<math> t= \frac{d}{v} </math>
Equating the two times:
:<math> \frac{d}{v} =\sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } + t_{pc} </math>
Solving for this distance: :<math> d = v \left( \sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } + t_{pc} \right) </math>
Equating this to the total stopping distance, which is the sum of braking and perception-reaction distances: :<math> v \left( \sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } + t_{pc} \right) = \frac{v^2}{2 g (\mu + e)} + v t_{prt} </math>
Isolating zero, and factoring out a v: :<math> v [ \frac{v}{2 g (\mu + e)} + \left( t_{prt} - \sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } - t_{pc} \right) ] = 0 </math>
Solving for the non-trivial case (or may distribute v in equation above and apply quadratic formula for same result): :<math> \frac{v}{2 g (\mu + e)} + \left( t_{prt} - \sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } - t_{pc} \right) = 0 </math>
The solution to the above equation, which provides the maximum safe speed as a function of horizontal setback, intercept acceleration, and road-tire friction coefficient: :<math> v = 2 g (\mu + e) \left( \sqrt{ \frac{ 2 d_i }{a_i} } + t_{pc} - t_{prt} \right) </math>
{{hidden end}}
===Case 4: Safe speed as a function of following distance===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of ACDA 4 |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }}
From the [[Equations of motion#Constant linear acceleration: collinear vectors|equations of motion]]:
:<math> t_g = \frac{d}{v} </math>
Isolating for speed:
:<math> v = \frac{d}{t_g} </math>
{{hidden end}}
===Case 5: Safe speed as a function of critical speed===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of ACDA 5 |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }}
[[File:Free body.svg|thumb|Forces on a vehicle skidding down a grade of angle ''θ''.]]
Starting with [[Newton's laws of motion#Newton's Second law|Newton's Laws of Motion]], the Laws of [[Friction]], and [[Centripetal force#Formula|Centripetal force]]:
:<math> F_\text{centripetal} \cos{ \theta } = F_\text{friction} + F_\text{gravity} \sin{\theta} </math>
Substituting formulas for [[Centripetal force#Formula|Centripetal force]], frictional force, and gravitational force:
:<math> m \frac{v^2}{r} \cos{ \theta } = \mu F_\text{normal} + m g \sin{\theta} </math>
The normal force is equal and opposite to the sum of the gravitational and centripetal components:
:<math> m \frac{v^2}{r} \cos{ \theta } = \mu (m g \cos{\theta} + m \frac{v^2}{r} \sin{ \theta } ) + m g \sin{\theta} </math>
Isolate <math>v</math> terms:
:<math> \frac{v^2}{r} \cos{ \theta } - \mu \frac{v^2}{r} \sin{ \theta } = g (\mu \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta} ) </math>
Then solve for <math>v</math>:
:<math> v^2 ( \cos{ \theta } - \mu \sin{ \theta } ) = g r (\mu \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta} ) </math>
To obtain: :<math> v = \sqrt { \frac{g r (\mu \cos{\theta} + \sin{\theta} ) } { \cos{ \theta } - \mu \sin{ \theta } } } </math> This is the full solution, however most corners are banked at less than 15 degrees (≈28% grade), so in such conditions, a fieldable small angle approximation may be used.
Substituting [[small-angle approximation]]s sinθ≈θ, cos≈1-θ<sup>2</sup>/2:
:<math> v \approx \sqrt { \frac{g r [\mu (1- \frac {\theta^2} {2}) + \theta ] } { 1- \frac {\theta^2}{2} - \mu \theta } } </math>
Exploit that a small angle squared, in radians, is insignificant by substituting θ<sup>2</sup>≈0 which obtains the formula used in case 5 (also tanθ≈e):
:<math> v \approx \sqrt { \frac{g r (\mu + \theta ) } { 1 - \mu \theta } } \approx \sqrt { \frac{g r (\mu + e ) } { 1 - \mu e } } </math>
{{hidden end}}
===Seconds of distance to stop rule===
{{hidden begin |toggle = left |title = Derivation of Seconds of distance to stop rule |titlestyle = |bg1 = |bg2 = |ta1 = right |ta2 = left |extra1 = font-size:100%; padding-right:2.5em; |extra2 = font-size:120%; padding-left:3em; }} The ''seconds-of-distance-to-stop rule'' is derived as follows.
We first obtain the total stopping distance and then convert it into travel time, which is more easily applicable by the driver.
:<math> d_\text{total} = d_\text{braking} + d_\text{perception-reaction} </math>
Invoking the [[Equations of motion#Uniform acceleration|equations of motion]],
:<math>d_\text{braking} = \frac{v^2}{2 a}</math>
:<math>d_\text{total} = \frac{v^2}{2 a} + v t_\text{prt}</math>
where
:<math>a=\mu g</math>.
The time it takes to casually traverse the stopping distance at the travel speed is
:<math>t=\frac{d_\text{total}}{v}</math>.
Substituting the former into the latter,
:<math>t=\frac{v}{2 \mu g}+t_\text{prt}</math>.
This can be simplified into the rule-of-thumb form
:<math>t=C \cdot v + t_\text{prt}</math>
by noting that
:<math>C=\frac{f}{2 \mu g}</math>.
Substituting (US Customary units)
:<math>\mu \approx \tfrac{7}{10}</math> (dry) or <math>\tfrac{5}{10}</math> (wet) or <math>\lessapprox \tfrac{2}{10}</math> (snow); <math>g \approx 32\;{\rm ft}\;{\rm s}^{-2} </math>, <math>f=\tfrac{22\;{\rm ft}\;{\rm s}^{-1}}{15\;{\rm mi\;h^{-1}}}</math> (convert mph to fps); <math>t_{prt}=1.5\;{\rm s}</math>,
we have
:<math>C=\tfrac{1}{30}</math> (dry), <math> \tfrac{1}{20}</math> (wet), and <math> \tfrac{1}{10}</math> (snow).
This results in a seconds-of-distance-to-stop rule (in MPH) of
:<math>t=\frac{v}{30} + 1.5</math> (dry pavement)
:<math>t=\frac{v}{20} + 1.5</math> (wet pavement)
:<math>t=\frac{v}{10} + 1.5</math> (snow, hard-packed).
The dry rule does allow one to travel faster in dry weather, but expect emergency deceleration to be a bit uncomfortable. If one desires to remember only one rule, use the wet one. However, because the difference between wet and dry is half-a-second at 30 MPH and one second at 60 MPH, and because dividing by two is easier than three, we can use a correctable rule of thumb:
:::<math>\color{Sepia}{t\approx\frac{v}{20} + 1 \quad \text{(general rule of thumb)}}</math> ''(instead add 2+ in wet or complex conditions, and also instead divide by 10 in snow/ice)''
For example, a speed of {{convert|60|mph}} corresponds to stopping distance of 4 seconds' travel at 60 mph. Drivers that require additional perception-reaction time, such as novices, elderly, or those in complex or adverse environments, can benefit by adding additional seconds.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Effects of uncertainty, transmission type, driver age and gender on brake reaction and movement time. |author1=Lora Warshawsky-Livne |author2=David Shinar |journal=Journal of Safety Research |volume=33 |issue=1 |date=Spring 2000 |pages=117–128 |issn=0022-4375 |doi=10.1016/S0022-4375(02)00006-3 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022437502000063 |quote=Perception-reaction time increased significantly from 0.32 to 0.42 s (P<.05) as uncertainty increased but brake-movement time did not change. Perception-reaction time increased (from 0.35 to 0.43 s) with age but brake-movement time did not change with age. Gender did not affect perception-reaction time but did affect brake-movement time (males 0.19 s vs. females 0.16 s).}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=On the speed of mental processes. |author=FC Donders |journal=Acta Psychologica |volume=30 |pages=412–31 |date=January 1969 |doi=10.1016/0001-6918(69)90065-1 |pmid=5811531 |issn=0001-6918 |oclc=1447968 |url=}}</ref>
The time to traverse your stopping distance at travel speed should not be confused with the braking time to come to a full stop, which is a number nearly twice this value ( {{math| <var>t</var>{{=}}{{sfrac|<var>v</var>|<VAR>μ</VAR> g}}+t<sub>ptr</sub>}} ). As one is continually slowing down while braking, it will naturally take longer to get to the stopping limit.
A more correct perception-reaction time of one-and-a-half seconds is commonly used by the mathematically inclined.<ref name="VA Table"/><ref name="Olsen&Sivak"/> Doing so to obtain your "seconds-of-distance-to-stop" for ''dry pavement'' and then converting time to actual distance by multiplying it by the travel velocity and {{math|{{sfrac|22|15}}}} to convert MPH to fps will yield results in close agreement with [http://law.lis.virginia.gov/vacode/46.2-880/ this table].
Whereas most driving is done below {{convert|80|mph}}, ''maintaining a blanket 5 or 6 seconds of travel time to the edge of visibility'' ({{math|<var>t<var>{{=}}{{sfrac|80|20}}+1}}), ''will keep drivers in compliance with the ACDA rule in most simple highway driving conditions – day or night'' – with growing error towards safety at lower speeds.
On final note, slope has an effect on stopping distance. An additional second or so will need to be added when stopping while traveling down a steep incline, and conversely driving uphill will improve breaking.<ref name="AASHTO"/> This is accounting that a level road was assumed in the rule of thumb. An urban or residential street which permits a maximum speed limit of 25 mph under its very best conditions (roadsides cleared of visual obstructions past a 20-foot maintained [[right of way]]), may in practice be unsafe to drive at more than 10 mph within sections with utilized curbside parking. This table also suggests that the safe speed could be greater than a statutory 25 mph posted speed, where roadside clearance is sufficient such that no "foreseeable" object could emerge from the proximate edge of roadside visibility, transect the cleared area, and intercept the lane before the driver could come to a halt. However, wary road design engineers may have differing views of foreseeable intercept speeds than that reflected by the 85th percentile speed chosen by the public. This can have unfortunate consequences where a mass commuting public is unfamiliar with or does not appreciate specific local hazards.
